author: pieterastra
content:
This does seem related to BZZ token, check the ERC-20 transactions on that contract.
And from https://docs.ethswarm.org/docs/installation/manual/:
> When running your Bee node with SWAP enabled for the first time, your Bee node will deploy a 'chequebook' contract using the canonical factory contract which is deployed by Swarm. A factory is used to ensure every node is using legitimate and verifiable chequebook contracts. Once the chequebook is deployed, Bee will deposit a certain amount of gBZZ (Goerli BZZ tokens) in the chequebook contract so that it can pay other nodes in return for their services.

author: pipermerriam
content: <@!543900561460822016> and <@!564718359304863744> you two should chat about the idea of getting a version of the eth1 protocol spec'd in the same manner as the eth2-specs.

author: voith
content: Hey <@!364458974906548225> did you mean to ping me? I'm a bit confused as I'm missing context.

author: pipermerriam
content:
I did indeed intend to ping you, and yes, makes sense that you're missing context.  So here's some context!

A long standing and unresolved issue has been "the yellowpaper".  It's our most complete protocol specification and it's incredibly difficult to contribute to or update, tends to lag behind the actual forks, and it's difficult to "version" it so discerning old fork rules isn't simple.

Over the years there have been a few efforts/attempts to create a new canonical spec.... they haven't gone anywhere.

The `eth2-specs` have been really successful in ways that the yellow paper and attempts to replace it haven't been so some of us have been thinking that it would be beneficial to re-write the yellowpaper in the eth2-specs format.  You might be interested in this project...  and so is <@!543900561460822016> .

author: voith
content: Thanks for the context. I'm totally interested in this project. Thanks for the ping. I will get in touch with <@!543900561460822016>
